docs.lead_paragraph: TRAVELS WITH A MEDIEVAL QUEEN By Mary Taylor Simeti Illustrated. 318 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $30. In 1186, Constance of Hauteville, accompanied by 150 mules loaded with treasure, was dispatched from Palermo by her nephew, William II, the Norman king of Sicily, to marry Henry VI of Germany. Henry was a Hohenstaufen and would become Holy Roman Emperor. The marriage was one of those shaky dynastic efforts to patch together a peace (never for long) among warring powers: in this case the empire, the Papacy and Sicily, which then included all of southern Italy.

docs.lead_paragraph: When an 11-year-old Sumatran rhinoceros named Emi gave birth to a pudgy, sloe-eyed calf at the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden on Sept. 13, biological scientists worldwide cheered. The calf, a male, was named Andalas, after the original name of the island of Sumatra, the largest island of Indonesia.

docs.lead_paragraph: One day, Jenny Potter will tell her daughter, Madison, about the unusual year Madison spent in locker rooms, dorm rooms and ice rinks, at dinner tables with 20 women, in the houses of kind nannies and aunts, on airplanes with her father, and, too often, away from her mother. Potter will tell Madison how she helped her mother train for the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics.

headline.main: Rookie Mom Keeps Focused on Hockey

docs.abstract: Profile of Jenny Potter, member of United States women's Olympic hockey team, who is juggling preparation for Winter Games in Salt Lake City, Utah, and motherhood; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Back in Dublin, she lied, telling her parents that she was going to work and her co-workers that she was sick. But Joanne M., 22 years old, single, and two months pregnant, did what thousands of other Irish women do every year in similar situations: she flew to England and had an abortion. Abortion is illegal in Ireland, an incontrovertible fact of Irish life that made Joanne's decision all the more difficult and her secret trip, when she resolved to make it, all the more necessary. There were her adamantly anti-abortion parents to worry about, she explained, and the stern teachings of the Catholic church, not to mention the social stigma attached to abortion in a country that prefers to pretend it hardly happens. And then there was the expense, about 800 Irish pounds, or roughly $900.

headline.main: Increasingly, Irish Turn to Britain for Abortions

docs.abstract: Number of Irish women having abortions in Britain is steadily growing, even though they must over considerable logistical, emotional and financial impediments; a lot are also having abortions at later stage of pregnancy, often because of delays in raising money; Irish opponents of abortion are pressing for referendum to make abortion unconstitutional, not just illegal, but measure would not affect 1995 law that made it legal to provide information in Ireland about how to obtain abortions in Britain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SEPT. 11-14 -- For four days and nights, network and cable news was a steadying presence in every living room and public space, with no commercials, no breathless hype, no fear-mongering, even as the images of airplanes crashing into the World Trade Center made viewers witnesses to horror as never before. Television was at its absolute best, a national touchstone offering information and emotional solace. DAVID LETTERMAN -- In his heartfelt return to the air after the attacks, he got everything just right: the tone of sadness in New York City, the need to return to everyday life, the difficulty of doing that. That Sept. 17 show was a reminder that he is by far the best of the late-night hosts, capturing what his audience needs and wants, including silly escapism.

headline.main: TELEVISION/RADIO: The Year in Television: The Critics' Choices; At Its Absolute Best in a Time of Terror

docs.lead_paragraph: The news that 80 percent of doctors' practices are not based on any scientific evidence certainly comes as no surprise to midwives and consumers of midwifery care (Jack Hitt). Such obstetrical protocols as forcing women to labor and deliver on their backs, performing mandatory episiotomies, hurrying labor along with pitocin and separating mother and newborn for ''observation'' have been shown, in the obstetricians' own research, to be harmful to mother and child. In the name of following procedure, hospital personnel enforce these pseudoscientific practices that interrupt the natural, and usually flawless, progression of pregnancy, labor, delivery, breast-feeding and bonding. And women who question any of it are tartly reminded who went to medical school and who didn't. Julie M. Goldberg Clifton, N.J.
docs.abstract: Julie M Goldberg letter on Jack Hitt's Dec 9 article holds standard obstetric practices are not based on scientific evidence
